Part 5: The Sixth Chapter on Spiritual Resonance, 5 Biographies of 13 People with Additional Biographies of 5 People, Biography of Rumin of Lingshu Temple in Shaozhou during the Later Tang Dynasty, Biography of Rumin of Lingshu Temple in Shaozhou during the Later Tang Dynasty, Monk Rumin was from Fuzhou.
He first met Chan Master An and then flourished in spreading the Dharma outside the mountain ranges. He truly had many extraordinary traces.

As for his character, he was easygoing, pure, and sincere. He rarely spoke without reason. He deeply pitied the deluded and ignorant, and often used his actions to inspire and encourage them.ğŸ”½The Liu family especially supported Panyu. They would often invite Rumin to come and ask questions. He often knew what was coming and his predictions were always accurate.
The rulers of Guang during the Later Tang Dynasty revered him and treated him with courtesy. They would often pay their respects and consult him when they had unresolved doubts.

Min had no aversion or suspicion, and when asked to compose, he would do so, all in accordance with the truth. At that time, it was called begging for a vow. He privately appointed him as the Great Master Zhi Sheng.
At first, Min had a practitioner of austerities as his attendant, who was quite in tune with his mind. He called him the one who is allowed.
One day, he followed him to the top of a mountain ridge and sent him back down. When he looked back, he saw Min enter the ground.
The practitioner of austerities hid in the grass, covering his form. After waiting for a long time, he came out and went to greet him, asking:
Where did the master go?
He said:
I have an old acquaintance with the mountain king. I was invited to have a conversation with him.
In this way, sometimes when someone died, he would dig a hole in the ground and come out.
He sternly warned him:
The one who is allowed should not speak of this outside. Revealing my idle affairs.
Later, he passed away in the monastery. His whole body was not scattered.
The government provided offerings for his funeral mound. Is this the true body stupa of Chan Master Lingxu?
The author says:
If Lingxu had met Daren, his life span would have been long and his years of practice would have exceeded the usual human limit.
I suspect this is also an unusual saying I have heard.
Later Tang Dynasty Biography of Quan Zai of Mount Tiantai, Mount Tiantai in Later Tang Dynasty. Shi Quan Zai, whose surname was Shen, was a person from Qian Tang.
When he was a child, he did not like meat and blood. His mother repeatedly saw good signs and encouraged him to become a monk under Dharma Master Fajie of Mount Jingshan.
When he practiced Chan meditation, he was lofty and aloof, not mingling with worldly dust. He admired the twelve dhutangas to adorn his practice. People called him Zhai the Chan practitioner.

Later, when he visited various places to study, he obtained the seal of approval from Chan Master Shishuang. He secretly cherished it and entered the Dark Cliff of Mount Tiantai to fulfill his aspiration. The cliff was opposite to the place where Hanshanzi lived in seclusion. Both places were filled with strange creatures and weird trees.
He lived there for more than twenty years, and the bad birds changed their voices, and the mountain spirits yielded their caves.

When he came and went and walked, ghosts and spirits took on tasks, either sweeping his path, or attending by his side, or fetching water for him, or offering to pick fruit. People sometimes saw this, but Zhai never spoke of it.
Later, in the fifth year of Tiancheng, the Chan monks of Jingshan went to welcome him back to Zhen Guoyuan, where he passed away in the monastery where he had originally left home.
Biography of Hui Jun of Badao in the Jin Dynasty, Biography of Hui Jun of Badao in the Jin Dynasty, Shi Hui Jun, whose place of origin is unknown.
As a monk, he was foolish and crazy, yet he could foresee things that had not yet manifested, and his responses were like those of a spirit.
During the Qianning period, for some reason he arrived in Badao.

Jun was also able to write in an unrefined style, and his calligraphy was natural. He would write Buddhist scriptures and Daoist teachings on the walls of temples, shrines, shops, and even vulgar songs and poems, all of which he would collect on the tip of his brush.
When spoken to, he would only say Awei.
The people of the village treated him as a sage.

The prefect Yu Gong, fearing that he would confuse the masses, imprisoned him and interrogated him. He then used poetry to convey his message, with the meaning being in the west and east of the Min River. However, the verses were all elegant, and the prefect found it strange and released him.
Furthermore, examining his meaning, it was suspected to be in the ocean. Could he be a descendant of Bei Du?
Whenever travelers passed by, they would always stop their boats to visit him - discerning the good and bad fortune of the upper and lower gorges, and the profitability of trading goods.
When travelers earnestly prayed, he would only write three to five lines, never clearly stating anything. His methods were subtle and secret, yet effective.
At that time, Zhou Chongbin, the chief military officer of Jingnan, visited him and wrote a message:
Entrusted to the imperial capital for examination.
Afterwards, when making tribute, due to the king's army attacking the south, he was eventually captured in the southern prefecture and executed.
Sun Daoneng, the military officer, visited him and wrote a character:
Entrust it to Zhulin Temple.
That year, he passed away and was buried at the site of the old Zhulin Temple.
Huangfu Xuan, the prefect, then painted a man carrying a school bag, with a girl by the side.
Soon, he took a girl from a commoner's family, and was sued, and his body was imprisoned in the yamen.

There was Mu Zhaoxi, a descendant of the Persian race, who, as a child, liked medicine and followed his father to pay homage to him. He then painted a Daoist riding on clouds, holding a gourd, and wrote: Commandery Marshal Gao Mou orders the yamen to investigate. Mu Zhaoxi later became effective in using medical techniques. The Prince of Nanping, Gao Conghui, ordered him to abandon Daoism and follow Confucianism, and appointed him as a yamen investigator.
When the royal army attacked Jingzhou, Jun wrote a poem to present to the Prince of Nanping, saying:
The horse's head gradually enters the road to Yangzhou, relatives and friends should wash their eyes and look.
That year, the Gao clan offered sincerity at Huaihai, and thus unraveled the heavy siege.
Other strange traces are mostly of this kind.
Once, he wrote on a banana leaf in the courtyard:
Today, repaying karmic debts, the county office has no more investigations.
Many passersby saw it, but he did not take it to heart.
Suddenly, he was harmed by someone, with his body and head in different places. The prefect had him cremated.

The Biography of Xingzun of Guangguo Temple in Langzhou of the Jin Dynasty, the Biography of Xingzun of Guangguo Temple in Langzhou of the Jin Dynasty. Shi Xingzun was the second son of King Wang of Fuzhou in Min.
After Emperor Zhuangzong of the Later Tang ascended the throne, he entered Luoyang to present local products, and stayed in the capital.
At the end of the Tongguang era, he encountered Emperor Ming's imminent entry, and the chaos of war continued. He then cut his hair, changed into monk's robes, and fled to Bazhou and Shu.
By the Kaiyun era of the Jin dynasty, his appearance was like that of a man in his seventies, but his physical strength did not decline.
When asked about his age, he would always remain silent.
He stayed at Guangguo Chan Temple in Langzhong. The disciples of the temple upheld the precepts, and people did not know whether they were able to follow them or not.
At a vegetarian feast hosted by the Li family, he suddenly got up, went out the door, and shouted as if he had something to accuse.
He said to Li:
Tonight there will be a fire, from southeast to northwest streets. All the neighbors should be prepared.
That night, it really happened, with nothing left.
The crowd gathered and asked him the reason. He said:
Yesterday a woman in red passed by with a torch. The old monk regretted not being able to catch up with her.
At Zhao Fuzhu's house, he pointed under a peach tree and said:
There is so much money.
He did not say the amount. Zhao then called people to dig it up. As they were just starting with shovels, they happened to meet a guest. It was taken by the servant.
In the midst of the commotion, it all turned into green mud. Each person scrambled to get a hundred or so, and later it was plastered over.
The gates and walls were often damaged.
Zun could sometimes know the good and bad fortune of a family by passing by their tombs.

As for wind, corners, birds, and beasts, he would predict disasters and blessings before hearing or seeing them, and later they would certainly match. Therefore, the people from far and near all used his predictions as the truth.
He passed away in Yushan, Jin'an, and the Buddhist disciples cremated him.
The Biography of the Unknown Monk of Xiangzhou in the Jin Dynasty, the Biography of the Unknown Monk of Xiangzhou in the Jin Dynasty, Shi Wuming, whose place of origin is unknown.
He traveled around to inquire about the Way, not shunning hardships.
He must have visited famous mountains and sacred sites.
During the Tianfu period, he arrived at a Chan monastery in Xiangzhou and hung up his robe and bowl, together with a monk who was kind and law-abiding, to observe the ninety-day summer retreat.
The man was orderly, and his words were often strange and exciting, calling himself Faben.
They lived together day and night, their minds were harmonious with each other, as if they had known each other for a long time, and Faben became his Dharma disciple.
Faben said:
The place where I study as a monk is in the Bamboo Grove Temple west of the capital city - in front of the temple there is a stone pillar.
If you have time another day, please come and visit me.
The monk remembered the previous agreement and went to inquire.
When he arrived at the village at the foot of the mountain, he stayed at a hermitage and asked the monks there:
How far is it from here to the Bamboo Grove Temple?
The monk pointed to the side of a solitary peak and said:
That is it.

The elders have passed down that it was once the dwelling place of sages and worthies, but now only the name remains. Therefore, there are no pure abodes or Buddhist halls established for the sake of the Buddha or the monks.
The monk doubted it, and the next morning he went there. When he saw the bamboo grove, there was indeed a stone pillar in the grove. He was confused and did not know its boundaries.
The monk remembered the words of Dharma Master Ben when they parted:
Just knock on the pillar and you will see the person.

He then used a small stick to strike the pillar several times, and suddenly the wind and clouds rose up all around, and he could not see anything within a few feet. In a moment, it cleared up, and the towers and terraces were towering before him. He was under the main gate.
After a while, Faben came out from inside and saw him, greatly delighted.

He asked about the old events in the south and spoke of the customs of Xiang and Deng. He then led him through the heavy gates and up to the secret hall, where he introduced him to the venerable elders, as if he were in charge.
He asked again and again, and Faben said:
In my early years in Xiangyang, we were in seclusion at the same time. We once made an appointment to visit each other, so I came to the mountain gate.
The venerable elders said:
Good.
You can come out after the meal. There is no seat here.
This means there was no position for an ordinary monk.
After the meal, Faben sent him to the main gate to say goodbye.
Then the sky and earth became dark and gloomy, and he did not know where to go.
After a while, he was back in the bamboo grove next to the stone pillar, but no one else could see it.
The monk came out and told the story, but he did not know the end of that monk.
Xi said:
Who was the monk who entered the bamboo grove?
Tong said:
The one who encountered the immortal is also an immortal. How could the holy temple allow ordinary defilements?
One shows that the Holy Temple is in the human world, and the other shows that the holy monk participates in the monastic community.
Do not treat the monk treasure lightly, as the ordinary and the holy are mixed together.
This biography was newly composed for several people, and has been heard in several places since ancient times.

For example, during the Wuping period of the Northern Qi, Shi Yuantong once saw a sick monk in the lecture hall. When the monk's summer retreat was over and his illness was cured, he made an appointment to come to Gushan Zhulin Temple in Yedu. The story is roughly the same.
This is probably because they arrived at the Holy Temple before and after.

Biography of the Mad Monk of Gaocheng County, Luoyang, Han Dynasty Biography of the Mad Monk of Gaocheng County, Luoyang, Han Dynasty Monk Cao, the Mad Monk, during the Kaiyun period of the Jin dynasty, begged for stone and ash in the villages, and drove them day and night into the two mountains of Daliu and Xiaoliu. He told passersby and villagers:
I want to build a palace.
However, no one could understand it, and they all said he was crazy, What is the basis for this?
In this way, he transported several thousand shi, and sealed them very securely.
Later, the villagers did not expect this monk to disappear completely.
In the beginning of the Qianyou era, the founder of the Han dynasty entered the present Eastern Capital and ascended the throne. He died in less than a year.
At that time, an imperial decree was issued to select a mausoleum on the mountain below Daliu. The planners said:
The number of bricks and tiles is several million. They can be made and fired in this mountain.
But where can we get the mineral ash?
Suddenly, a local official said:
This place originally had a large store of ash accumulated by monks, which can be counted in the thousands of bushels, enough to be used.
After investigating the mountains and hills, not a single remnant was used. The monk was not crazy, and this is where he was proven.
Furthermore, Shi Cao Heshang of Zhenzhou was a person from Hengyang.
He did not stay in one place, his words were incoherent, he wore a torn robe and tattered shoes, his face was dirty and his skin was dark, and he was called a madman and a vagabond.
People from Qi and Zhao did not understand him, but many respected him.
Sometimes he was invited to eat, and after finishing his meal, he would leave in silence, his appearance like that of someone who is not drunk but angry.

The prefectural commander An Chongrong had been stationed there for several years, and he urged the military officials and the people of the prefecture to request the court to establish a stele for virtuous deeds.
On the day the stele was to be erected, its appearance was upright.
Cao Heshang pointed at it and laughed loudly, saying:
It cannot be erected, it cannot be erected.
Everyone looked at each other with pale faces, and the host drove them away, but Cao still did not stop talking.
When the great honor secretly sprouted unrighteousness, grooming horses and sharpening weapons, he was about to rebel. The imperial court exterminated him, and the stele was soon destroyed.
Everything he pointed out was like an echo answering a sound.
Later, it is unknown where he ended up.

The Biography of Monk Jian of Jingzhong Temple in Fake Shu of the Zhou Dynasty, the Biography of Monk Jian of Jingzhong Temple in Fake Shu of the Zhou Dynasty, the Biography of the Unknown Monk of Dacisi, Monk Jian, whose secular name was Jian, had the surname Wang and was a person from Jingzhao.
When young, he was perceptive and wise, with extraordinary eloquence.
In the eleventh year of the Dazhong era, when Du Shichang's strategy was completed, Feng Juan, the Director of the Imperial Secretariat, was in the same year.
During the Qianfu era, the rebellions of the Nest King were rampant, and he followed the flow to avoid the chaos.
He arrived at Zhugong and surrendered to Cheng Rui, the Prefect of Zhong. Rui attacked Huaihai, but was unsuccessful, so he shaved his head and left the household life.
Lei Man controlled Jingzhou, and Xiangzhou Zhao Ning attacked and destroyed it.
The ancestor of the Liang Dynasty sent Gao Jichang to exterminate it, and Jiangling then belonged to the Gao family.
Jian avoided staying in the area between Kuizhou and Yuzhang.
In the third year of the Tongguang era of the Later Tang Dynasty, he entered Shu and searched for Feng Juan, who had already died.
He then stayed at Jingzhong Temple, with white beard and hair, and a ruddy complexion, carefree, people did not know his true feelings.

There was a scholar from Hanyang named Wang Chuhou - in the year bingwu, he failed the examination in the pseudo Shu, which was the second year of the Zhou Xinding era - he entered the temple and wrote his worries among the pine and bamboo, and saw Jian.
Jian said:
Could it be Wang Chuhou?
Chuhou was surprised and said:
We have never been acquainted, why do you call me so suddenly?ğŸ”½Jian said:
I just know.
He then told him that he was born in the first year of the Dali era of the Tang Dynasty, Emperor Xianzong, and it had been over 130 years since then.
Chu Hou said:
What about my whereabouts?
Your future events end next year.
And from now on, things can be known.
He meant that Shu would perish, and told him not to divulge it.
The next day, he searched again, but the sound and trace disappeared.
One day, he knocked on the gate and came in himself, saying:
I'll go pay respects to Emei temporarily, and return after spending the summer at Heishui.
He sealed it on the desk and picked up the scroll to read it. It was Chu Hou's prefectural examination essay, which said:
Examining the authenticity, it is not a text illuminated by your candle.
Why so much deception?
He then took out the essay and showed it to him, saying, Isn't this the original true copy from the prefectural examination?
Chu Hou was startled and said:
After the examination, I occasionally added some polishing to make up for the mistakes made in a hurry under the candle.
Where did you get this copy?
Jiam said:
Not only this one post, but everything you have done in your life is recorded here.

The next day, he visited and took Chu Hou into the northern corner of the temple, together they visited the shrine of the former Grand Commandant, Duke of Bin, Du Cong, and sat under the western wing. Suddenly, several officials in miscellaneous attire came out in a row from the buildings, descended the steps and kowtowed twice. Jian said:
The new official is here, you can go to court to report.
Chu Hou was frightened and anxious.
Jian said:
These people will be your drivers, why be afraid?
Do you know that Mount Tai has appointed you as the Director of Fate?
Moreover, because of your past debts and grand plans, you have not fulfilled your previous aspirations, please wait until after you pass the examination to carry them out.

Furthermore, I checked the official salary register and saw that the number of people on the spring examination list has already been determined, and you are also among them. This is the yin note and yang receipt.
You have received the fame in the human world and the salary in the netherworld. This is the yang nourishing the yin and receiving.
Chu Hou was shocked and did not know what to do, but he asked:
Who are the people who will pass the exam next year?
He immediately wrote a short letter and gave it to him, warning him:
Keep it very secret.
If it leaks, disaster will follow immediately.
In a moment, the officials dispersed.
Chu Hou took his hand out of the temple and left in the dark.
When spring came and the exams were over, Chu Hou came to Hou's house and left a note saying:
I will return to my humble hut and will not see you again.
Later, he went to the monks' hall in the temple to ask about him, but he had already left.
He then opened the short letter and saw only four lines written: Zhou Cheng and Cheng, the two kings have different names, Wang resides in one of them, and the period is 100 days.
When the results were posted, it was verified that there were indeed eight successful candidates.
The two kings, Hou and Wang Shenyan, lived in one place.
He disliked the hundred days as a standard, and Hou only associated with those of the same age, setting up a high gathering with wine, to the utmost delight of nature.
Because of this, chaos did not arise, and he died violently that night.
Those of the same age all dreamed that Hou, in a blue robe and holding a tablet, drove the palace and left.
Examining the name of his strategy, it ended in one hundred and twenty days.

In detail, the sealing of his life began in the first year of Emperor Wenzong's Taihe era, and his body was completed during Emperor Xuanzong's Dazhong era. Wang Hou met him at over one hundred and thirty years old.
Next, the pseudo-king, a monk of unknown name from Dacisi in Shuocheng, always chanted the Lotus Sutra, making people enjoy listening to it.
When it was time to go begging for alms, he would take enough.
If he had minor ailments, he would show him prescriptions.
The monk took his staff and entered Qingcheng Dumen Mountain to collect medicine.
Crossing the dangerous rapids, suddenly clouds and fog arose in all four directions, and he did not know where to go.
After a while, he saw an old monk who greeted him, exchanging greetings and asking why he had come here.
The monk said:
I am here to collect some herbs.
The old man said:
The farmhouse is not far, can you slightly detour on your spiritual feet?
The monk said:
I am lost and have lost my way, I wish to follow the gentleman.
After a while, the clouds dispersed and he saw a house with shady trees.
When they got closer, the old man said:
Let's first report to the master of the farmhouse.
When the monk entered the gate, he saw things that were all extraordinary.
He asked:
Is there any food?
He said:
Not yet.
The incense was burning and he suddenly felt an unusual fragrance, and asked to recite the sutra he was practicing.
The monk recited the sutra in a loud voice, urging him to recite it all the way through.
The food provided was all the food in front of Dacizisi Temple.
After the meal, a blue-robed attendant carried a bamboo basket and offered fragrant herbs, then gave him five strings of cash to buy Hu-style pastries.
The old man clasped his hands and saw him out.
Someone asked, saying:
This is Mr. Sun Simiao.
It had already been over a month since he arrived at the temple.
When the money was about to enter the temple, it turned into a spring of gold coins.
The Wang family heard about it and collected the gold coins, separately giving him five hundred strings of cash.
The monk scattered it to the people. It can be known that the immortal man always resides in famous mountains.
Next, in Luomei County, Jiazhou, there was a complaint:
Sun Shanren borrowed a donkey but did not pay the fee. Please order him to be arrested.
Asking the young boy, he said:
This is Sun Simiao.
The county magistrate was startled and paid the fee instead.
The man lived under the mountain. When he came out of the county road, he saw Sun Gong taking two hundred coins and giving them to him, saying:
I have been waiting for you here. Why are you suddenly surprised?
The monk who obtained the gold coins did not know his final whereabouts.
Zhou Shijian, a monk of Huaguang Temple in Hangzhou, had the surname Zhao and was from Danqiu.
He did not follow the precepts, was unrestrained and complacent, wore patched robes, recited many verses, and liked to predict disasters and blessings in Huzhou and Yuezhou.
At first no one believed him, but the predictions were as accurate as a tally.
He had a special skill in geomancy and geography based on the Yijing and Jingchun Shanjing. He often said:
In the past, Dao Bian of Mount Tai used geomancy to select grave sites, but there is nothing else worth taking.
He enjoyed helping people move their graves, and the results were as he predicted.
He had no fixed residence and often visited wealthy families. When he said he was hungry, he would ask for chicken meat to eat.
If he obtained delicious wine outside, he would drink several cups and leave.

At first, he did not express his gratitude, but he was good at writing official documents - large-character signboards, temple gate plaques, and so on. When he finished writing, he would make predictions about good and bad fortune, which were verified over time.
At first, he lived in a temple by the West Lake in Hangzhou, and passed away without illness.
Later, a traveler saw him in the market of Changsha, holding hands and chatting with him as old friends. He entrusted a message to the abbot of Chongshou Temple:
You previously owed me some money, which I now let you off.
I am sleeping on the lower layer of straw mats, with some paper wrapped around meat jerky crumbs, which must have gone bad by now, so please throw it away.
The temple monk followed his instructions and found it to be true, so he wrote his portrait for worship.
Jian Zeng said, After the pointed roof, he will be cremated.
Sure enough, in the Wu Wu year of the southern pagoda of the state, it was burned by a heavenly fire, and his words were not wrong.
Biography of Arhat Wang of Qianfu Temple in Mingzhou, Song Dynasty Biography of Arhat Wang of Qianfu Temple in Mingzhou, Song Dynasty Shi Wang Luohan was an inscrutable monk.
He was fond of pork, and his words seemed like those of a madman, but later many things he said turned out to be true.
Once, when he was wearing tattered clothes, a thief was about to steal them, but he lowered his head and pretended to be asleep.
When people came to ask for things, he never showed any stinginess.

In the sixth month of the first year of the Kaibao era, he suddenly died sitting, and three days later he was wrapped in lacquer cloth. Suddenly, a sound of smacking was heard from his cheeks, and people said it was rotting.
At night, he entrusted a dream to several people, saying:
The lacquer cloth is making me dizzy. How can I open it?
The next day, he called the lacquer craftsman to peel it open. The flesh was red and white, and round grains of relics fell out. They were collected and enshrined.
To this day, his flesh body remains in the original temple.
At that time, Sengzheng Zanni wrote a stele recording the wonders.
The king of the Han-nan kingdom, the Qian family, privately changed his name to the Venerable Xiu Shenhua.

Biography of Zonghe of Yan Shou Temple in Tanzhou, Song Dynasty. The Biography of Zonghe of Yan Shou Temple in Tanzhou, Song Dynasty. Dao Yin, Shi Zonghe, was a person from Min Yue. He traveled to Mount Heng and sailed on the Xiang River to seek teachers.
As a monk, he was upright and had few desires. He lived with the group all day, only smiling.
The people of Nan Chu mostly believed and respected him.
Later, he lived in Yan Shou Temple. The former Jianshi Dajiang Jia Gongci, who ruled the military headquarters, heard about him and went to visit him. Their conversation did not connect.
The people in the carriage discussed, saying, How can a person who has attained the Way enter the realm of ordinary people?
Jia then firmly invited him to be the abbot of Wenshu Temple.
On that day, he ascended the seat, briefly raised the essentials of Chan, and dispersed.
The next day, he told the assembly:
For some reason, I will temporarily leave. You virtuous ones should not detain me.
He packed as if he were going on a journey, crossed the Peng Canal, and stood still in front of the Huangzhou post station, where he passed away.
People from far and near rushed to pay their respects.

At that time, the envoy of the horse station took care of the funeral affairs and built a stupa at the place where he stood still, which was the second year of the Kaibao era. This is probably the present Zhen Shen Temple.
Furthermore, Shi Daoyin of Dayan Temple in Weichi was from an unknown place.
He roamed between Weichi, Peng, and Jian, and said to himself:
As a monk, if one abides by frugality, then one will not bother others.
If one associates with animals, then one will not have right and wrong filling one's ears.
He once raised a black dog, and they went out, rose, and lay down together, never parting.
Every time he ate, he used an iron bowl to cook over the fire. When the porridge was done, he ate it with the dog.
Sometimes they went out together, sometimes not, their actions were strange and unusual, and no one could fathom them.
One day the monk passed away, and the dog also died sitting up.
Now, the statue of him is sculpted in Dangan Temple, and his physical body is preserved in two places. This happened during the Kaibao era.
People in Luoyang have deep faith in him, and incense and flowers fill his niche.

The Biography of Shi Diandian, the Monk of Lingjiushan Temple in Daye, Song Dynasty. The Biography of Shi Diandian, the Monk of Lingjiushan Temple in Daye, Song Dynasty. Shi Diandian was a monk whose origin is unknown.
During the Guangzheng era of the Meng clan, he lived in a mountain temple in Daye, south of Ying, often wandering among the markets.
Although he had shaved his head and dyed his robes, he always seemed insane.
When he interacted with people, he would point and speak, thus he was called by this name.
Those who were ordered to provide him with vegetarian food would not avoid alcohol and meat, considering it normal, and vulgar people did not dislike it either.
In the evening, he would buy yellow and white hemp paper, brushes, and ink, put them in his sleeves, and return home.
After walking a few li, he would fall into a deep sleep.
The room where he lived had an outer door but no four walls.
After entering, he would close the door and no one could enter.

At first, a young monk from a neighboring temple tiptoed to spy on him. He saw [the monk] holding a candle, sitting with legs crossed, with paper and brush in front of him, scolding and writing in large characters, but he could not understand the words.
He often sighed as if making decisions and arrangements.
After a long time, when it was bright and dark, he looked carefully, and it seemed as if there were many people standing, shaped like officials, wearing vests and skirts that were not worldly attire.
The observer was frightened and retreated.
The next morning, when slightly inquiring about the matter, [the monk] was angry and did not answer.
After living there for several years, the people of Ying and Ze all regarded him as a spiritual prodigy, and later no one knew his end.
The author comments:
The master could summon ghosts, but he had no other lofty and pure conduct to guide people to do good. Was he the same as those of the past who judged affairs in the netherworld?
The author replies:
What one does is in the mind. If it does not arise from the power of the right path, then it is the same as the Way of the Five Pecks of Rice.
If it does not arise from a mind with spells and prohibitions, then it is simply the response of ghosts and spirits to faith and the urging of the mind.
Therefore, the Sutra of Good Admonitions says:
If one needs spiritual powers to respond and transform to liberate, one should manifest spiritual powers.
In the Treatise on the Adornment of the Sage's Stupa, the bodhisattva uses spiritual powers and transformations as play and joy.
Moreover, this may be a person in the stage of practice of the pratyekabuddha, so the treatise says:
The pratyekabuddha relies on this and that village to beg for food, to liberate himself through the body.
